column2: name
description
An improvement over being unarmed, these metal rings augment their holder's punches nicely.
Longswords have good accuracy, damage, and parrying ability, helping their bearer excel in every battle.
A curved blade attributed mystical power that can make effortless quick slices with impressive accuracy.
A wide-bladed two-handed sword that mixes the savagery of an axe with the precision of a sword.
An elegant dueling weapon that is sharp all along its blade; ideal for thrusting attacks and parries.
Not quite a knife or a sword, Shortswords are heavier than they look, but can still be swung quickly.
This sharpened chef's implement is just as good at slicing up a steak as it is slashing living flesh.
Some call them tomahawks, others hunga munga; this is a throwing axe by any name.
A medium-sized axe balanced for carving wood rather than throwing, it can carve flesh just as well.
It's hard to beat this two-handed axe when it comes to overkill; the destruction these wreak is legendary.
It's an axe on a pole, the pole ends in a spear, and there's also a hook on the pole; clearly this is versatile.
Anything blade-like attached to the end of a pole, for sweeping slices at a comfortable distance.
Among the least effective ways to kill someone, but great for confusing or disarming foes while keeping your hands free.
A heavy one-handed tool converted into a weapon of war that is especially strong against armor.
A brutal two-handed sledgehammer that seems impractical against all but the slowest foes -- or monsters.
A plain-old heavy stick that can be swung with surprising speed, and can be passed off as a normal twig.
Not just any stick, this one's made of solid metal, and can pulverize armor with a good wallop.
Whether an collapsible pole or just a piece of bamboo, a Pole is excellent at whacking multiple foes.
An unusual mix of a spear's pointed tip with a shield-shaped haft, usually made entirely from hard wood.
Lighter than a Lance and heavier than a Javelin, a Shortspear can be effectively wielded at close to medium range.
An uncommon weapon, the Lance can't attack a close-by enemy but can annihilate further-away foes.
A heavier mid-length spear with a broad leaf-shaped blade at the end; it can be used for slicing and stabbing alike.
A martial-arts weapon consisting of two club-like bars connected with a short chain; excellent for defensive use.
A series of three or more wooden rods connected with chains; originally meant for threshing rice but deadly when swung.
A nasty spiked ball whipped around on a heavy chain; it's simply brutal against armored foes.
A small, heavy weight on the end of a long vine or rope; making one is easy, but fighting with one is very hard.
A leather bullwhip that's flexible enough to knock a weapon from the hands of nearby opponents.
A metal chain that can be spun to deliver painful strikes, and can wrap around an enemy's weapon to relieve him of it.
A martial-arts weapon with three curving spikes that provide ample ability to disarm foes.
A fishing spear adapted for gladiatorial and maritime combat, the trident has three barbed prongs on a mid-size pole.
A lightweight, deeply-curved blade that can be used for severing plant roots, or a foe's limbs, as well as disarming.
A sword-like weapon with a heavy blade that goes straight and then curves; challenging to wield and to confront.
A hook-bladed farming tool meant for slicing wide swaths of grain, adapted to slicing wide swaths in necks.
A shield that's meant for actively parrying and blocking enemy attacks, mixing in quick jabs with the edge of the shield.
A large shield that's effective at defending even while barely moving, but it's hard to precisely wield one.
A heavy wooden shaft that's been augmented with razor-sharp stone blades along its edge; incredibly dangerous.
A smaller bow that isn't as unwieldy in close-quarters combat as a Longbow, and isn't as conspicuous when carried.
A very large bow, usually taller than its wielder, that boasts tremendous range and hefty power.
A small machine that launches a bolt with the pull of a trigger; slow to reload, but capable of piercing thick armor.
A weighty machine that can launch a bolt in an instant, but takes a long time to reload; makes up for it with huge power.
This hand-held firearm is very imprecise, but that doesn't always hinder it because its bullet keeps bouncing after missing.
A heavy two-handed firearm with better accuracy than a Pistol and longer range, but more lengthy reload times.
An early stone-hurling weapon made from cord and hide, it has considerably better range than throwing a rock by hand.
A curved staff with cords to hold a projectile at one end, this weapon improves a Sling's range even further.
A bladed hoop with just as much use at medium range as in melee combat, it can be drawn quickly and thrown far.
A chunk of hard wood, carefully fashioned into a hunting weapon that spins all around the target when it misses.
A very light spear that's primarily meant for throwing, but can be used as a melee weapon in desperate situations.
A simple-looking device that enables a spear to be thrown much further, and with greater precision, than it can by hand.
A throwing weapon, shaped like a star or tiny blade, that deals pitiful damage but can be laced with poison.
A simple projectile weapon that allows a quick exhalation to propel a needle at the target; usually the needle is poisoned.
A pair of weights linked with a cord that can be thrown with a spinning motion to entangle a target's legs or arms.
A heavy mesh with barbed weights on the edge that could be used for fishing or ensnaring fugitives.
A precursor to other firearms, this is a container of shrapnel and blast powder that causes brutal damage when it works.
A simpler model of firearm that has advanced in parallel to the Musket, this weapon fires a shell in a very long arc.
A well-balanced, light-weight knife that is primarily meant to be thrown, but is also usable in close combat in a pinch.
A small round crystal that a Mystic wielder can use to disrupt the energy flow of an enemy, or supplant a friend's.
A deck of many fortune-telling cards, each decorated with cryptic imagery; an interpretation can be used as a Mystic curse.
A mysterious stone that seems fated to belong to a Mystic wielder; to such a bearer it grants esoteric powers.
A gift of the land to those who protect it, this massive stony tooth carries Primal power over rock and soil.
A garland of leaves that lives without soil or water thanks to a Primal blessing; it can grow thorny vines to attack.
A hide shield inscribed with ancient symbols that beseech the land for protection; fiendish creatures shy away from it.
When carried by a Blessed wielder, this sacred icon can issue shining judgment even when simply worn or carried.
A ritually-purified holy text that serves to channel Blessed faith into waves of divine wrath against transgressors.
A necklace made of hundreds of tiny stone beads; Blessed wielders can throw the beads to channel divine wrath at targets.
An Occult wielder's best (or only) friend, this black book, bound in some kind of skin, can obliterate nearby enemies.
A rusted antique, this appears to be an ordinary lantern until lit with Occult magic, which makes it project a death ray.
A five-sided crystal shaft with motes of otherworldly light dancing inside it; Occult wielders can strike with this odd glow.
A thick Arcane encyclopedia, laden with enchantments that can drive off enemies who come too close.
A strong effort by Arcane wielders to one-up firearms, this staff with various gems and sigils on it can fire energy blasts.
A small but carefully-crafted wooden rod that enables Arcane wielders to manipulate magic strength in themselves and others.
The somber nation of Zedmedov uses unarmed combat to resist undead raiders that frequently tear through its land.
The island conglomerate of Cheuritae favors unarmed combat that takes advantage of chaotic battlefields, such as ships.
The proud state of Hyrden goes on crusades against monsters; they often mix swordplay with unarmed combat.
The alliance of tribes from the Mbegonda region uses improvised weapons to make their unarmed combat interesting.
The honor-bound empire of Otekai does not teach unarmed combat, but their ninja enemies rely on it heavily.
The aristocracy of Jalgeaux likes to use a flashy sort of unarmed combat that makes enemies overestimate a practitioner.
The frozen lands of the Ikkutiq people are rich in magic, and their unarmed combat often seems like a ritual dance.
The fiercely-self-ruled nation of Ugexiir teaches its people vigilance against all enemies, whether they are armed or not.
The desert lands of Hidzaajji are home to a fighting style which emphasizes movement that flows like silk.
The Kobold nation of Laathrik teaches unarmed combat that consists almost exclusively of dirty tricks and low blows.
The isolated land of Hueztotli practices a hard-hitting form of unarmed combat meant mainly for subduing monsters.
The merchant-ruled state called Keungeuh practices unarmed combat that exerts control over the enemy's movement.
The steppe nomads of the Khainghal clan primarily use bows, but they practice unarmed combat with similar precision.
The pious nation of Bididhayi teaches a "thunderbolt" school of unarmed combat that strikes quickly with grabs and throws.
The Goblin nation of Mobyuld teaches a sneaky style of unarmed combat based around striking pressure points.
The nation of Chobesh collapsed after a century of war, so what's left emphasizes making do with minimal equipment.
The Elf nation of Elethian loves swordplay, and their unarmed combat similarly emphasizes balance and parrying.
The Orc culture of Krort likes big, heavy weapons, but they like it even more when an Orc can hit hard without one.
